texts.definition: Goals that require the player to maintain a subset of a certain game state within certain limits.
markups: <style="Definition">Goals that require the player to maintain a subset of a certain game state within certain limits.</style>

Goals in games are defined by what goal states players need to achieve. However, some goals require this state (which may not need to be one exact state but rather a small subset of the possible states of the game) for some time. Those that do are <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> since players not only need to reach an acceptable game state but also continue keeping the game state in an acceptable state until sufficient time has passed.

Multiplayer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%201942">Battlefield 1942</link></style> have modes where teams score points (or reduce ticks from the opposing team) by controlling strategic locations.

The goal for the king in <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style> is to maintain the game state of being the king while the other players have the goal of changing that game state. The same situation appears in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tag">Tag</link></style>, but reversed; the chasing player, "it", has a goal to change the game state by role reversal while the other players try to maintain the state.

Games where players try to avoid detection, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Thief%20series">Thief series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed series</link></style>, provide <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> in the form of sneaking and stealth.

<style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> are often used to give players gameplay tasks or requirements that they need to pay attention to while doing other things. This means that <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> can be used to require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style> from players and create <style="Link"><link="attention-demanding-gameplay">Attention Demanding Gameplay</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> can be constructed around <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Continuous%20Goal">Continuous Goal</link></style> whose failure mean that the game ends for the player.

There are several ways of creating <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style>. Many other types of goals are by their nature normally continuous, e.g. <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="king-hill">King of the Hill</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="reconnaissance">Reconnaissance</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="repeat-combos">Repeat Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style>. Other emerge from the presence of game elements, e.g. <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> gives players <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> of not losing these. Games with <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> similarly create a goal for players as long as they play to increase their <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Indirect%20Control">Indirect Control</link></style> of game elements can also give rise to <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> if several players or <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> compete for the control (that is, they all have the potential for indirectly controlling the game elements). The combination of <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style> show how actions in themselves can become <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style>, in this case simply the goals to complete an action. Games with <style="Link"><link="sustenance-rewards">Sustenance Rewards</link></style> imply a continued need to what the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> provides, and this is likely to be the source of a <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goal</style>. <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> lets players set goals for themselves and these can be <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> if they depend on the players not failing with certain things. Diegetic structures in a game can also provide the starting point for <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style>, e.g. that <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> or that players belong to, or have relations to, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>.

There are two categories of <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style>: those that have a predetermined length of time that they need to be maintained and those that depend on other facts. Members of the first category can be created simply by adding explicit <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> to a <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goal</style> but also occur naturally when the length of the current part of gameplay for which the goal is relevant is known. Examples of the latter include <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="survive">Survive</link></style> (as long as there are no <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> to the gameplay where the goals are relevant).

<style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> can also be used as building blocks for certain other patterns. For example, <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> are basically <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> that have <style="CurrentLink">Continuous</style> <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> to players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. As another case, <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> that relate to <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> and require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> can create <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dynamic%20Alliances">Dynamic Alliances</link></style>, and even <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Organizations">Social Organizations</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style> can be used to make <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> have to stretch over several game sessions. This is likely to create more <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> can both be modified by linking them to <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style>. In the first case, one way it to provide more or better <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> the longer the goal has been maintained (typically beyond a certain minimum). In the second case, players may not be able to resolve the dilemma in any definite way but have to handle the dilemma over a longer period of gameplay time.

<style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Goal%20Points">Goal Points</link></style> can both be added to some <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> to let players have indications of their progress as well as allowing partial successes of the goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> makes goal have <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> and add <style="Link"><link="time-pressure">Time Pressure</link></style> to a game. Through this, the pattern also adds <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>. The existence of <style="CurrentLink">Continuous Goals</style> may also make players consider <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>.
